metadata.synopsis:
Asharak has been tasked with getting civilians prepared for war. He hopes having the player on their side might make the difference.
If the tiefling leader is dead, Asharak reluctantly steps into his shoes.

12.speaker: Asharak
12.text: On to the city. After what you showed us, I damn well pity any who try and keep us out.

20.speaker: Asharak
20.text: Well - are we ready? Tymora's spun her coin, and I would see which way it lands.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: As we'll ever be. Let's go.

32.speaker: Asharak
32.text: Let the bastards know we're waiting for them.

10.speaker: Player
10.text: Hold on - what's the plan again?

6.speaker: Asharak
6.text: Simplest strategy there is: draw them in and burn them faster than they can burn us.

100.speaker: Asharak
100.text: Sound the horn - let the bastards know we're waiting for them.

36.speaker: Player
36.text: Give me a moment. I have more to do.

72.speaker: Asharak
72.text: Aye, fair enough. Just don't take too long.

43.speaker: Asharak
43.text: I'd sooner start this on our terms than theirs.

31.speaker: Asharak
31.text: Won't pretend I expected to see you back again. Bloody glad, mind.

95.speaker: Asharak
95.text: People are scared. Zevlor's doing what he can, but...

96.speaker: Asharak
96.text: Well. Seeing you on the walls might put the steel in their spines. Mine, too.

33.speaker: Asharak
33.text: We're ready to celebrate. Are you?

108.speaker: Player
108.text: I'm ready to go to camp now.

18.speaker: Asharak
18.text: Best news I've heard all day.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: I'll let you know when I'm ready.

38.speaker: Asharak
38.context: NodeContext: Resigned - never thought he'd be training children to fight.

59.speaker: Asharak
59.text: Gods, thought I was seeing a bloody ghost. How did you survive the goblin camp?

106.speaker: Asharak
106.text: More importantly - what happened? We've spotted them massing in the woods.

41.speaker: Asharak
41.text: My students are down in the cave. With wooden bloody swords, Torm spare me.
41.context: NodeContext: Resigned - never thought he'd be training children to fight.

47.speaker: Asharak
47.text: We've just got word - the goblins have cleared out. And I hear it's you we have to thank.
47.context: NodeContext: Delighted - impressed and proud of you.

30.speaker: Asharak
30.text: Here - it's not much, but it's yours. Zevlor ordered a collection, before...
30.context: NodeContext: Giving us a reward, and being reminded that his leader is either dead or disappeared. Trailing off to a painful memory (pulling himself back to the present in his next lines)

83.speaker: Asharak
83.text: Before he passed. But the time for mourning's done. I mean to celebrate.
83.context: NodeContext: First sentence stating a painful truth about their leader having died, but firmly pulling himself back to be pragmatic and positive.

84.speaker: Asharak
84.text: Though - you might want to speak to Halsin first. He turned up a short while ago.

56.speaker: Asharak
56.text: He's having words with Kagha. Reckon you don't want to miss that, but come find us after.

70.speaker: Asharak
70.text: My people would be honoured to join your camp tonight, if you'll have us. We're ready to go when you are.

69.speaker: Asharak
69.text: Watching gods - while I was training children, you were out cutting down an entire goblin camp.
69.context: NodeContext: Grimly relieved - he's found out you're on his side. Wyll = Will

74.speaker: Asharak
74.text: Wyll told me you gave us up to the goblins - bloody glad he had it wrong.
74.context: NodeContext: Grimly relieved - he's found out you're on his side. Wyll = Will

54.speaker: Asharak
54.text: We'll need every blade if we're to make a fight of this.

75.speaker: Asharak
75.text: You've cleared the way for us - as clear as it gets, anyway. Thank you.
75.context: NodeContext: He's relieved to see you, but warning of the impending attack - player might just have jumped out of the frying pan and into the fire.

76.speaker: Asharak
76.text: Watching gods, but you're a prettier sight than any I expected to see today.
76.context: NodeContext: He's relieved to see you, but warning of the impending attack - player might just have jumped out of the frying pan and into the fire.

24.speaker: Asharak
24.text: I'd given you up for dead at the goblin camp - and our hopes along with you.
24.context: NodeContext: You've just told him he's facing insurmountable odds, and he's reacting with fear but resigned pragmatism. His outlook tends to be of the 'Murphy's Law' variety

14.speaker: Asharak
14.text: What happened?! We've spotted goblins massing in the woods.
14.context: NodeContext: You've just told him he's facing insurmountable odds, and he's reacting with fear but resigned pragmatism. His outlook tends to be of the 'Murphy's Law' variety

66.speaker: Player
66.text: I met the drow commanding them - and led her here.
66.context: NodeContext: You've just told him he's facing insurmountable odds, and he's reacting with fear but resigned pragmatism. His outlook tends to be of the 'Murphy's Law' variety

62.speaker: Asharak
62.text: A... a drow? Why the hells would you bring her here?

46.speaker: Player
46.text: She tricked me. But I mean to make up for it.

60.speaker: Asharak
60.text: 'Make up for it'? How the bloody hells -

29.speaker: Asharak
29.text: Gods damn it, I'm sorry. I know you wouldn't draw her on us.

90.speaker: Asharak
90.text: Not after you've already saved us once before. We'll need your help again now.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: All part of the plan. I'll give the signal and she'll march into our trap.

81.speaker: Asharak
81.text: Trap a drow? Easier trap a spider in its own damned web!

79.speaker: Player
79.text: It's a trap - and she's waiting for my signal. Don't quibble with me now.

27.speaker: Asharak
27.text: A trap? We're the ones backed into a corner here, I'd say.

78.speaker: Asharak
78.text: But... aye, I trust you, Torm spare me. You've seen us right once before.

68.speaker: Asharak
68.text: If we've got any chance at all, it'll be with you on our side.

17.speaker: Player
17.text: To burn the grove, of course. For the glory of the Absolute.

89.speaker: Player
89.text: It's a full war-band, led by a drow.
89.context: NodeContext: You've just told him he's facing insurmountable odds, and he's reacting with fear but resigned pragmatism. His outlook tends to be of the 'Murphy's Law' variety

37.speaker: Asharak
37.text: ...A drow. Right - I'd say I'm surprised, but Beshaba's had her mark on us since Elturel.
37.context: NodeContext: You've just told him he's facing insurmountable odds, and he's reacting with fear but resigned pragmatism. His outlook tends to be of the 'Murphy's Law' variety

19.speaker: Asharak
19.text: No two ways about it, now - a fight it'll have to be.
19.context: NodeContext: Fatalistic, discarding any hope of escape but steeling himself for the fight

98.speaker: Asharak
98.text: You helped us throw them back once before - fancy doing it again?
98.context: NodeContext: Forced lightness, camraderie - he needs you to say yes

88.speaker: Player
88.text: Their drow commander found the grove - and she means to take it.
88.context: NodeContext: You've just told him he's facing insurmountable odds, and he's reacting with fear but resigned pragmatism. His outlook tends to be of the 'Murphy's Law' variety

109.speaker: Asharak
109.text: ...A drow. Right - I'd say I'm surprised, but Beshaba's had her mark on us since Elturel.
109.context: NodeContext: You've just told him he's facing insurmountable odds, and he's reacting with fear but resigned pragmatism. His outlook tends to be of the 'Murphy's Law' variety

80.speaker: Asharak
80.text: You don't owe us any apologies - but I'll take your help, if you're offering.
80.context: NodeContext: Upset, the player has given up the entire tiefling grove for slaughter.

2.speaker: Player
2.text: No, you don't get it. I'm with them.
2.context: NodeContext: Upset, the player has given up the entire tiefling grove for slaughter.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: No - you can't! I trusted you!
3.context: NodeContext: Upset, the player has given up the entire tiefling grove for slaughter.

1.speaker: Wyll
1.text: No - you can't! I trusted you!
1.context: NodeContext: Upset, the player has given up the entire tiefling grove for slaughter.

93.speaker: Wyll
93.text: Traitor. The Blade now comes for you.
93.context: NodeContext: It takes him a moment to realise what he's being told - that the player has betrayed them and sided with the goblins.

49.speaker: Player
49.context: NodeContext: It takes him a moment to realise what he's being told - that the player has betrayed them and sided with the goblins.

91.speaker: Asharak
91.context: NodeContext: It takes him a moment to realise what he's being told - that the player has betrayed them and sided with the goblins.

77.speaker: Asharak
77.text: You've turned on us? Hells, why?

39.speaker: Player
39.text: I have a god to please, and Bhaal loves murder.

44.speaker: Player
44.text: I have a god to please, and Myrkul loves a slaughter.

67.speaker: Player
67.text: I have a god to please, and Bhaal loves murder.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: I have a god to please, and Myrkul loves a slaughter.

50.speaker: Asharak
50.text: Well to the hells with you - and your god and all. Guards! Weapons!

65.speaker: Player
65.text: Simple - the goblins are a lot more useful to me.

16.speaker: Player
16.text: For the glory of the Absolute. Why else?

64.speaker: Asharak
64.text: Well to the hells with you, then. Guards - weapons!

4.speaker: Player
4.text: What do you think? Ready for battle - and leave the drow to me.
4.context: NodeContext: You've just told him he's facing insurmountable odds, and he's reacting with fear but resigned pragmatism. His outlook tends to be of the 'Murphy's Law' variety

104.speaker: Asharak
104.text: ...A drow. Right - I'd say I'm surprised, but Beshaba's had her mark on us since Elturel.
104.context: NodeContext: You've just told him he's facing insurmountable odds, and he's reacting with fear but resigned pragmatism. His outlook tends to be of the 'Murphy's Law' variety

25.speaker: Asharak
25.text: But if you're willing to spit in Lady Doom's eye along with us, I won't turn you down.
25.context: NodeContext: Faint, joking - forced humour but knows no-one is buying it

13.speaker: Asharak
13.text: Who knows - with your help, might be we can even make a fight of it.
13.context: NodeContext: Faint, joking - forced humour but knows no-one is buying it

61.speaker: Player
61.text: Of course. Tell me what you need.
61.context: NodeContext: Faint, joking - forced humour but knows no-one is buying it

15.speaker: Asharak
15.text: Hah! Enough warriors to make this a fair fight. Failing that, we've got the means to make it unfair.
15.context: NodeContext: Faint, joking - forced humour but knows no-one is buying it

7.speaker: Asharak
7.text: That's why our every ounce of anything that goes boom is buried out in front of that gate.
7.context: NodeContext: Acknowledging his plan is terrible but knows it's the only option.

107.speaker: Asharak
107.text: Once we're ready, we'll draw 'em in to that spot. Then it's down to fire-arrows and prayer.
107.context: NodeContext: Acknowledging his plan is terrible but knows it's the only option.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: We'll have to lure them in first.
102.context: NodeContext: Acknowledging his plan is terrible but knows it's the only option.

86.speaker: Asharak
86.text: You said it's a drow in charge, yeah? They ain't stupid, so I hear - but they are proud.

5.speaker: Player
5.text: A bold plan - but a risky one.
5.context: NodeContext: Acknowledging his plan is terrible but knows it's the only option.

58.speaker: Asharak
58.text: Not so risky. Drow are cunning buggers, aye - but proud too, the way I hear it.
58.context: NodeContext: Acknowledging his plan is terrible but knows it's the only option.

22.speaker: Asharak
22.text: That horn can be heard half the world away - let's issue a challenge, eh?
22.context: NodeContext: Acknowledging his plan is terrible but knows it's the only option.

82.speaker: Player
82.text: That's it? Please tell me you've thought of another option.
82.context: NodeContext: Firm. He's reached a decision, even if it is a dangeorus one.

57.speaker: Asharak
57.text: Burning drow sounds a pretty good option to me - but we'll have to get her here first.
57.context: NodeContext: Firm. He's reached a decision, even if it is a dangeorus one.

0.speaker: Asharak
0.text: That horn can be heard half the world away - let's issue a challenge, shall we?

85.speaker: Asharak
85.text: She's expecting to find us broken - let's show her just what a mistake she's made.

63.speaker: Player
63.text: Come. It's time to paint the place red.

55.speaker: Wyll
55.text: Come. It's time to paint the place red.

8.speaker: Player
8.text: That's the stupidest damn plan I've ever heard.
8.context: NodeContext: Smiling, laughing, acknowledging his plan is terrible but knows it's the only option.

97.speaker: Asharak
97.text: No doubt - but thick as I might be, I reckon this drow is likely twice as proud.
97.context: NodeContext: Smiling, laughing, acknowledging his plan is terrible but knows it's the only option.

40.speaker: Asharak
40.text: Fact is, we can't beat 'em - not in a fair fight. So best make it as unfair as possible, eh?

92.speaker: Player
92.text: You've reinforced the place - those barricades might even hold.

73.speaker: Asharak
73.text: Oh aye, we've been busy. Fact is, we won't win in a fair fight - so best make it as unfair as we can.

87.speaker: Asharak
87.text: To think I was scared of a bloody drow. Should've known better - we had you.

34.speaker: Asharak
34.text: Gods, they're going to want a bloody speech, aren't they?
